instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
There was damage on <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R3512</RESISTOR>, so i replaced those two, and also replaced <CHIP>U3510</CHIP>, 

When i plug in charger after about 5 seconds fan does a small kick/spin, 

Any ideas, thank you guys in advance


<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>: 0V
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.59V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.431V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.336V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.035V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.341V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: pulses twince when plug in then drops to 0.50v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: pulses twince when plug in then drops to 0.0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: pulses twince when plug in then drops to 0.50v


<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL>: pulses once at plug in

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>:3.32v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: 3.32V

<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: 3.429V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Check if all secondary coils pulse; maybe not from CPU.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulses too?

Use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads instead of power button.
Check signals reaction every time.

Try to start in SMC bypass also...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - when i plug power cord pulses 3.4v twice then stops.

when i use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> goes to 0.57v then back to 0v

pardon my stupidity, but i do not know how to start in SMC bypass :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28 of the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>? Corrosion near <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Press power button (or use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads instead), connect magsafe and mantain pressed 5-10s.
Google also knows that...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Resistance between pins 17/18 - 3.5 ohms and 27/28 - 20 ohms of the [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/isl6259ahrtz.html"]<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>[/URL]

Corrosion near [URL="https://store.rossmanngroup.com/e1-slg3nb148cv.html"]<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>[/URL], <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>, or <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, NONE AT ALL

it was all clean except on <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: How about SMC bypass like was asked? Do this by disconnecting all power sources (Battery + Magsafe) and having the power button pressed (or with <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16) while plugging the charger in. Keep the button pressed until the device powers on, if it doesn't do that after 15 seconds you can give up because it should've started already. Make 100% Sure the power button (or eqv.) is pressed when any power source is applied or the SMC will be booted and you would need to disconnect all power again first

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message: SMC bypass still not coming on,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Minor damage on/around <TRANSISTOR>Q3510</TRANSISTOR>
threads.message:
Check resistors and traces around SPI chip <CHIP>U6100</CHIP>.
Also try new BIOS, just in case...
